newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican business czar slams central bank policies.
newsitem.headline: Mexican business czar slams central bank policies.

text.p: Prominent Mexican businessman Eugenio Clariond Reyes made a stinging attack on the Banco de Mexico on Tuesday, saying the central bank's focus on inflation risked a new devaluation of the currency.

"I want to ask the sensible leaders of the country to not let themselves be influenced by the Banco de Mexico. The principal cause of our economic troubles, the cause of the devaluations over the past 30 years, has been the innocent yet dreadful revaluation of the peso," he told a crowd of business leaders.

Clariond Reyes, one of the top businessmen in this northern city and chairman of steel company Grupo Imsa, spoke at a conference of the Mexican Institute of Financial Executives this week. He is also the brother of Nuevo Leon governor Benjamin Clariond Reyes.
He accused the central bank of focusing excessively on cutting inflation. "Our monetary authorities have as their only and absolute purpose in life...to reduce inflation to one digit."
April inflation was 1.08 percent in Mexico, bringing price increases over the last 12 months to around 22.5 percent.
"The problem is that if the trend that we have seen in 1996 and 1997 continues, we will certainly be heading toward an over-valuation," Clariond told the top business conference.
Mexicans have been wary of a repeat of the December 1994 peso devaluation that plunged the economy into its worst recession in six decades.
Clariond also targeted a poor internal savings record as another consequence of the "dreadful revaluation-devaluation policy".
